subject: Philosophy
title: The Is-Ought Problem
description: A quick, practical guide to The Is-Ought Problem.

hook.text: Nature is violent. Animals kill to survive. Does that mean humans should too?

buildup.text: David Hume noticed you can't logically jump from 'this is how things are' to 'this is how they should be.'

discovery.text: Facts describe the world. Values prescribe behavior. They're different kinds of statements.

twist.text: People constantly smuggle 'oughts' into 'is' claims. 'Natural' doesn't mean 'good.'

climax.text: Hume's insight remains a foundation of moral philosophy. You can't derive ethics from biology alone.

punchline.text: What is and what ought to be are different questions.

quiz.question: What is Hume's is-ought problem?
options: You can't derive moral rules from factual descriptions
Science can solve all moral questions
Morality is based on natural law
